\begin{abstract}
We introduce a combined macroscopic/microscopic transport approach 
employing relativistic hydrodynamics for the early, dense, deconfined stage 
of the reaction and a microscopic non-equilibrium model for the later hadronic
stage where the equilibrium assumptions are not valid anymore.
Within this approach we study the dynamics of hot, bulk QCD matter, which
is expected to be created in ultra-relativistic  heavy ion collisions
at the SPS, the RHIC and the LHC.
Our approach is capable of self-consistently calculating the
freeze-out of the hadronic system, while
accounting for the collective flow on the
hadronization hypersurface generated by the QGP expansion.
 In particular,
we perform a detailed analysis of the reaction dynamics,
hadronic freeze-out, and transverse flow.
\end{abstract}
